_exec_summary.SummaryText:
for the chlorination facilities, a deficiency
  was identified with the design of the chlorine room exhaust ventilation systems.  The current systems
  in the six chlorine rooms do not meet criteria established by the Chlorine Institute.  There is a 
  proposed completion date of June 2001 for a project to modify the existing systems to meet Chlorine
  Institute specifications.

  To further improve the safety of the chlorination facilities, a plan is being considered to replace the
  manifold-mounted vacuum regulators in the RCW chlorine rooms with container mounted vacuum
  regulators similar to those at the water treatment facility.  This will eliminate the pressurized manifold
  and transfer hose assembly which further reduces the potential for a release.   This effort should be
  completed by June 2001.

equipment.  Container patches and
  plugs specifically designed for use on the types of chlorine containers used at  PGDP are available
  to the Plant Emergency Squad.

7.4  Training

  Personnel assigned to the ERO are required to satisfactorily complete an initial training program prior
  to assignment.  ERO personnel are trained to respond to hazardous material emergencies.  Required
  continuing or refresher training for hazardous material emergency response is conducted annually.

  The formal training program includes classroom type training (lectures and seminars), practical
  applications (tabletop drills, functional drills, and exercises), and self-study programs developed for
  ERO and support personnel.

7.5  Drills

  Drills involving hazardous material response are conducted annually for the Plant Emergency Squad
  on each shift.  PGDP participates biennially in an Emergency Management Exercise which involves
  a number of off-site organizations.

7.6  Public Warning System

  The public warning system, consisting of outdoor warning sirens and emergency alert systems
  announcements, is used to provide emergency notification.  Operations testing of the public warning
  system sirens is conducted monthly.

7.7  Coordination With Off-Site Organizations

  Mutual aid agreements, memorandums of understanding, and letters of assistance have been entered
  into with off-site groups to provide assistance in the event of an emergency.  These support services
  encompass areas such as medical assistance, fire control, evacuation, ambulance services, and law
  enforcement.

  The Emergency Management organization coordinates required emergency planning activities with
  local and state agencies including the Kentucky Division of Emergency Management and the Paducah-McCracken County Disaster and Emergency Services.  Emergency planning is also coordinated with
    DOE. 8.   PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

  During the development of the Process Hazards Analysis

.   RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THE PADUCAH GASEOUS DIFFUSION PLANT

                        EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


1.   INTRODUCTION

  The United States Enrichment Corporation (USEC) has prepared a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for
  the Paducah Gaseous Diffusion Plant (PGDP).  The RMP is in accordance with the requirements set
  forth in 40 CFR Part 68.  The PGDP plant is subject to Process Safety Management (PSM) and RMP
  requirements.


2.   MANAGEMENT AND ORGANIZATION

  USEC is committed to conducting operations in a manner that protects the health and safety of the
  workers and the public, and protects the environment.  In order to meet these commitments, USEC
  has issued an operations policy manual which states, in part:

     USEC is ultimately responsible for, and is committed to, safe operations,  maintenance, design,
     fabrication, and testing of the . . . Paducah Gaseous Diffusion Plant . . . and is committed to
     conducting operations in a manner that protects the health and safety of workers and the public,
     protects the environment, and provides for the common defense and security.

  Program and staff organizations are established for safety, safeguards and quality, and environmental,
  safety, and health with sufficient resources to support the line organization in safe operation of the
  plant.


3.   GENERAL DESCRIPTION


3.1  Facility Description

  PGDP enriches uranium using the gaseous diffusion process.  PGDP is located on a 3,425-acre site,
  of which 748 acres are within the controlled plant security fence.  The entire facility is owned by the
  United States Department of Energy (DOE).

  USEC leases and operates a  portion of the plant. The portion of PGDP leased by USEC contains
  more than 115 buildings with a total floor space of about 8 million square feet.  Four large enrichment
  process buildings constitute approximately 75 percent of the plants' total floor space.  There are also
  cooling towers, electrical switchyards, and

several support operations structures, including sewage and
  liquid effluent treatment plants, decontamination and recovery operations, coal and ash-handling
  facilities, water treatment facilities, steam plant, maintenance operations, laboratories, fluorine
  facilities, and air plants.

  Buildings, facilities, and areas not leased by USEC are owned and operated by DOE.

  This RMP applies only to facilities leased by USEC. 3.2  Regulated Substances

  Chlorine is the only substance listed in 40 CFR 68.130 which is present in quantities exceeding the
  threshold quantity.  Chlorine is managed in accordance with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119
  PSM program.

3.3  Use of Regulated Substances

  Raw water is taken from the Ohio River, treated and supplied to PGDP for numerous uses.  A portion
  of the water is filtered and post-disinfected, using chlorine, and used to supply potable water, fire
  system water, cooling water, and other uses.  Raw water treatment takes place at the C-611 Water
  Treatment Plant which is located to the west of the plant.  Chlorine is used at two locations at C-611. 
  One location has two containers with one container connected to the manifold system, and one
  location with four containers of which two are connected to the manifold system at any time.

  A portion of the water treated at C-611 is provided to the recirculating cooling water (RCW) system. 
  This system provides cooling water to the enrichment process.  RCW is treated with chlorine, via
  chlorinators in four RCW pump houses,  to control the growth of microorganisms in the RCW system. 
   Two pump houses have two 1-ton containers with one container connected to the manifold system,
  and two pump houses have four 1-ton containers of which two are connected to the manifold system
  at any time.

  Chlorine is also stored in 1-ton containers at a storage yard near the western boundary of the fenced
  area and at a storage yard near the C-611 facility. 


4.   ACCID

ENT SCENARIOS


4.1  Worst-Case Scenarios

  Chlorine is used at the site water treatment plant and the four RCW pump houses.  At the water
  treatment plant and two of the pump houses, two 1-ton containers are connected to the chlorination
  system.  The worst-case scenarios involve the release of the total contents of both containers (4,000
  pounds).

  The toxic endpoint for the worst-case release scenario, determined using RMPComp, was
  approximately 3 miles.  Within this 3-mile radius are included private residences, small businesses, 
  an electric power generating plant, schools, churches, and a state wildlife management area.

  At two of the pump houses, only one 1-ton container is connected to the chlorinator at any time.  In
  the cylinder storage yard the release scenario assumed a single container failure.  Therefore, the
  release of 4,000 pounds of chlorine from one of  the three locations with two connected containers
  constitutes the worst-case scenario.

4.2  Alternative Scenarios
  
  The alternative scenario involved the release of the contents of two containers (4000 pounds),
  assuming a connecting hose failure.  The toxic endpoint for this case, determined using the ALOHA
  program, was approximately 1.4 miles.  Within this radius are included private residences, churches,
  small businesses, and a portion of a state wildlife management area.  


5.   FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

  There have been no major releases of chlorine involving injury to site workers,  environmental effects,
  or any impact to the public within the past five years.  Chlorine releases have been limited to small
  leaks from manifolds and manifold connections.


6.   ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

  Chemical safety at PGDP consists of the integration of environmental, safety, and health management
  systems to address chemical safety.  Chemical safety controls are designed to mitigate the adverse
  affects of the toxic materials used in the enrichment process

e specific facility maintenance organizations and the
  manufacturer's recommendations, develops maintenance and inspection requirements and criteria for
  chemical systems.  These chemical safety requirements are based on PSM program requirements for
  the particular system.

  Maintenance of chemical systems is performed in accordance with the facility maintenance programs
  that include the PSM Mechanical Integrity program for systems covered under PSM.

  Maintenance work packages are prepared to provide the necessary technical and safety guidance for
  maintenance activities.

6.5  Preventive Maintenance

  Manufacturer's recommendations are used as guides for preventive maintenance on specific chemical
  systems and equipment.  Equipment installed or maintenance services provided by contractors for
  chemical systems are tested and inspected by the contractor as required by the contract for that project. 
  PGDP personnel also perform independent inspection and testing.

6.6  Quality Considerations

  Independent overview of maintenance activities on chemical hardware is addressed by the Quality
  Assurance and Configuration Management programs, as applicable.  These independent programs
  include:
  
     Procurement Quality Requirements
     Construction Inspection
     Testing and Pre-Operational Inspection
     Pressure Vessel Inspection
     Crane Inspection
     Operational Readiness Review and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs
     Plant Operations Review Committee

6.7  Configuration Management (CM)

  The CM program is applicable to chemical systems.  The plant CM Program includes an
  organizational structure and administrative process and controls to ensure that accurate, current design
  documentation is maintained that matches the plant physical configuration.

  In accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119(i), a pre-startup safety review is performed for new or modified
  facilities when the change is significant enough to require a change to process safe

to workers, the public, and the
  environment.  To achieve this objective, safety analyses, process hazard analyses, and industrial
  hygiene and safety programs are utilized.


6.1  Systems

  All chlorine feed facilities are equipped with manifold- or container-mounted vacuum regulators which
  reduce the pressure of the chlorine from the vapor pressure of the liquid chlorine in the container to
  a partial vacuum.  Loss of vacuum for any reason causes the vacuum-regulating valve to close the gas
  supply, minimizing the release in the event of a break in the manifold.

  All chlorine feed facilities are equipped with chlorine detectors which provide alarms to plant
  personnel in the event of a release.

  Manually operated, remote valve closing rods are administratively required to be in place on the stem
  of open 1-ton chlorine container valves.  These valves can be operated from outside of the chlorinator
  rooms in the event of a release from the manifold system.

6.2  Procedures

  Plant procedures are prepared in accordance with the requirements of a formal procedure system.  The
  procedure program includes the development, review and approval, revision process, distribution, and
  procedure configuration management.  Specific procedures for the operation and maintenance of
  chlorine systems and the handling of chlorine cylinders are managed within this procedure system.

6.3  Training

  Employee training is conducted by a dedicated training organization.  Personnel who operate,
  maintain, manage, handle, and have emergency response duties for chemicals covered by PSM are
  adequately trained for the particular chemical system or related activity.

  If activities performed by non-PGDP personnel (contractor personnel) interface with chemical systems,
  appropriate training and guidance is required.  PGDP representatives provide guidance for training and
  job performance.

6.4  Maintenance and Inspection

  The Engineering group, in conjunction with th

ty information.  The
  pre-startup safety review is an independent review to address the readiness of the system hardware,
  associated hazard controls, personnel (including required training), and procedures.  If the change does
  not require a change to process safety information, a pre-startup safety review is not performed.


7.   EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

  PGDP maintains a written Emergency Plan.  The Emergency Management organization is responsible
  for maintaining and updating the plan as appropriate.


7.1  Organization

  The Emergency Response Organization (ERO) is responsible for taking immediate mitigative and
  corrective actions to minimize the consequences of an incident involving the release of toxic
  substances (including chlorine) to workers, public health and safety, and the environment.  The ERO
  is staffed with trained personnel who respond to events and are required to participate in formal
  training, drills, and exercises.

  The ERO includes the Plant Emergency Squad consisting of the following:

     Plant Shift Superintendent (PSS)
     Police operations
     Fire Services
     Operating shift, nonsupervisory, supervisory, and specialist personnel

  The site ERO is staffed 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.  The  on-duty PSS, the senior manager on
  shift, is responsible for the implementation of the emergency plan.

7.2  ERO Actions

  In the event of an emergency, such as a chlorine release, the PSS takes the following actions:

     Takes actions to ensure the safety of plant personnel and the general public
     Takes actions to ensure safe operations/activities of the plant
     Classifies the emergency and makes required notifications, if necessary
     Performs assessment actions
     Performs any other emergency actions as appropriate

7.3  Emergency Response Equipment

  Emergency equipment at PGDP includes detectors and alarms, communications equipment, personnel
  protection equipment and spill/release containment and cleanup
